sn11.22:4.4: “Once upon a time, mendicants, there was a native spirit who was ugly and deformed. He sat on the throne of Sakka, Lord of Gods.
sn11.22:4.5: But the gods of the Thirty-Three complained, grumbled, and objected:
sn11.22:4.7: This ugly and deformed spirit is sitting on the throne of Sakka, Lord of Gods.’
sn11.22:4.8: But the more the gods complained, the more attractive, good-looking, and lovely that spirit became.
sn11.22:5.1: So the gods went up to Sakka
sn11.22:5.2: and told him what had happened, adding:
sn11.22:5.8: ‘Surely, good sir, that must be the anger-eating spirit!’
sn11.22:6.1: Then Sakka went up to that spirit,
sn11.22:6.2: arranged his robe over one shoulder, knelt with his right knee on the ground, raised his cupped palms toward the anger-eating spirit, and pronounced his name three times:
sn11.22:6.3: ‘Good sir, I am Sakka, Lord of Gods! Good sir, I am Sakka, Lord of Gods!’
sn11.22:6.4: But the more Sakka pronounced his name, the uglier and more deformed the spirit became.
sn11.22:6.5: Until eventually it vanished right there.
sn11.22:6.6: Then Sakka, the Lord of Gods, guiding the gods of the Thirty-three, recited this verse:
sn11.22:7.2: I’m not easily drawn into the maelstrom.
sn11.22:7.3: I don’t get angry for long,
sn11.22:8.1: When I do get angry I don’t speak harshly,
sn11.22:8.2: nor do I advertise my own virtues.
sn11.22:8.4: out of regard for my own welfare.’”
